lines.text: Enter CELIA and ROSALIND

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: I pray thee, Rosalind, sweet my coz, be merry.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Dear Celia, I show more mirth than I am mistress of and would you yet I were merrier Unless you could teach me to forget a banished father, you must not learn me how to remember any extraordinary pleasure.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Herein I see thou lovest me not with the full weight that I love thee. If my uncle, thy banished father, had banished thy uncle, the duke my father, so thou hadst been still with me, I could have taught my love to take thy father for mine: so wouldst thou, if the truth of thy love to me were so righteously tempered as mine is to thee.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Well, I will forget the condition of my estate, to rejoice in yours.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: You know my father hath no child but I, nor none is like to have: and, truly, when he dies, thou shalt be his heir, for what he hath taken away from thy father perforce, I will render thee again in affection by mine honour, I will and when I break that oath, let me turn monster: therefore, my sweet Rose, my dear Rose, be merry.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: From henceforth I will, coz, and devise sports. Let me see what think you of falling in love

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Marry, I prithee, do, to make sport withal: but love no man in good earnest nor no further in sport neither than with safety of a pure blush thou mayst in honour come off again.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: What shall be our sport, then

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Let us sit and mock the good housewife Fortune from her wheel, that her gifts may henceforth be bestowed equally.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: I would we could do so, for her benefits are mightily misplaced, and the bountiful blind woman doth most mistake in her gifts to women.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Tis true for those that she makes fair she scarce makes honest, and those that she makes honest she makes very illfavouredly.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Nay, now thou goest from Fortunes office to Natures: Fortune reigns in gifts of the world, not in the lineaments of Nature.
Enter TOUCHSTONE

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: No when Nature hath made a fair creature, may she not by Fortune fall into the fire Though Nature hath given us wit to flout at Fortune, hath not Fortune sent in this fool to cut off the argument

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Indeed, there is Fortune too hard for Nature, when Fortune makes Natures natural the cutteroff of Natures wit.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Peradventure this is not Fortunes work neither, but Natures who perceiveth our natural wits too dull to reason of such goddesses and hath sent this natural for our whetstone for always the dulness of the fool is the whetstone of the wits. How now, wit! whither wander you

lines.speaker: touchstone
lines.text: Mistress, you must come away to your father.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Were you made the messenger

lines.speaker: touchstone
lines.text: No, by mine honour, but I was bid to come for you.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Where learned you that oath, fool

lines.speaker: touchstone
lines.text: Of a certain knight that swore by his honour they were good pancakes and swore by his honour the mustard was naught: now Ill stand to it, the pancakes were naught and the mustard was good, and yet was not the knight forsworn.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: How prove you that, in the great heap of your knowledge

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Ay, marry, now unmuzzle your wisdom.

lines.speaker: touchstone
lines.text: Stand you both forth now: stroke your chins, and swear by your beards that I am a knave.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: By our beards, if we had them, thou art.

lines.speaker: touchstone
lines.text: By my knavery, if I had it, then I were but if you swear by that that is not, you are not forsworn: no more was this knight swearing by his honour, for he never had any or if he had, he had sworn it away before ever he saw those pancakes or that mustard.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Prithee, who ist that thou meanest

lines.speaker: touchstone
lines.text: One that old Frederick, your father, loves.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: My fathers love is enough to honour him: enough! speak no more of him youll be whipped for taxation one of these days.

lines.speaker: touchstone
lines.text: The more pity, that fools may not speak wisely what wise men do foolishly.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: By my troth, thou sayest true for since the little wit that fools have was silenced, the little foolery that wise men have makes a great show. Here comes Monsieur Le Beau.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: With his mouth full of news.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Which he will put on us, as pigeons feed their young.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Then shall we be newscrammed.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: All the better we shall be the more marketable. Bon jour, Monsieur Le Beau: whats the news
Enter LE BEAU

lines.speaker: le beau
lines.text: Fair princess, you have lost much good sport.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Sport! of what colour

lines.speaker: le beau
lines.text: What colour, madam! how shall I answer you

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: As wit and fortune will.

lines.speaker: touchstone
lines.text: Or as the Destinies decree.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Well said: that was laid on with a trowel.

lines.speaker: touchstone
lines.text: Nay, if I keep not my rank,

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Thou losest thy old smell.

lines.speaker: le beau
lines.text: You amaze me, ladies: I would have told you of good wrestling, which you have lost the sight of.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: You tell us the manner of the wrestling.

lines.speaker: le beau
lines.text: I will tell you the beginning and, if it please your ladyships, you may see the end for the best is yet to do and here, where you are, they are coming to perform it.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Well, the beginning, that is dead and buried.

lines.speaker: le beau
lines.text: There comes an old man and his three sons,

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: I could match this beginning with an old tale.

lines.speaker: le beau
lines.text: Three proper young men, of excellent growth and presence.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: With bills on their necks, Be it known unto all men by these presents.

lines.speaker: le beau
lines.text: The eldest of the three wrestled with Charles, the dukes wrestler which Charles in a moment threw him and broke three of his ribs, that there is little hope of life in him: so he served the second, and so the third. Yonder they lie the poor old man, their father, making such pitiful dole over them that all the beholders take his part with weeping.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Alas!

lines.speaker: touchstone
lines.text: But what is the sport, monsieur, that the ladies have lost

lines.speaker: le beau
lines.text: Why, this that I speak of.

lines.speaker: touchstone
lines.text: Thus men may grow wiser every day: it is the first time that ever I heard breaking of ribs was sport for ladies.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Or I, I promise thee.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: But is there any else longs to see this broken music in his sides is there yet another dotes upon ribbreaking Shall we see this wrestling, cousin

lines.speaker: le beau
lines.text: You must, if you stay here for here is the place appointed for the wrestling, and they are ready to perform it.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Yonder, sure, they are coming: let us now stay and see it.
Flourish. Enter DUKE FREDERICK, Lords, ORLANDO, CHARLES, and Attendants

lines.speaker: duke frederick
lines.text: Come on: since the youth will not be entreated, his own peril on his forwardness.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Is yonder the man

lines.speaker: le beau
lines.text: Even he, madam.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Alas, he is too young! yet he looks successfully.

lines.speaker: duke frederick
lines.text: How now, daughter and cousin! are you crept hither to see the wrestling

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Ay, my liege, so please you give us leave.

lines.speaker: duke frederick
lines.text: You will take little delight in it, I can tell you there is such odds in the man. In pity of the challengers youth I would fain dissuade him, but he will not be entreated. Speak to him, ladies see if you can move him.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Call him hither, good Monsieur Le Beau.

lines.speaker: duke frederick
lines.text: Do so: Ill not be by.

lines.speaker: le beau
lines.text: Monsieur the challenger, the princesses call for you.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: I attend them with all respect and duty.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Young man, have you challenged Charles the wrestler

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: No, fair princess he is the general challenger: I come but in, as others do, to try with him the strength of my youth.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Young gentleman, your spirits are too bold for your years. You have seen cruel proof of this mans strength: if you saw yourself with your eyes or knew yourself with your judgment, the fear of your adventure would counsel you to a more equal enterprise. We pray you, for your own sake, to embrace your own safety and give over this attempt.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Do, young sir your reputation shall not therefore be misprised: we will make it our suit to the duke that the wrestling might not go forward.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: I beseech you, punish me not with your hard thoughts wherein I confess me much guilty, to deny so fair and excellent ladies any thing. But let your fair eyes and gentle wishes go with me to my trial: wherein if I be foiled, there is but one shamed that was never gracious if killed, but one dead that was willing to be so: I shall do my friends no wrong, for I have none to lament me, the world no injury, for in it I have nothing only in the world I fill up a place, which may be better supplied when I have made it empty.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: The little strength that I have, I would it were with you.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: And mine, to eke out hers.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Fare you well: pray heaven I be deceived in you!

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Your hearts desires be with you!

lines.speaker: charles
lines.text: Come, where is this young gallant that is so desirous to lie with his mother earth

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: Ready, sir but his will hath in it a more modest working.

lines.speaker: duke frederick
lines.text: You shall try but one fall.

lines.speaker: charles
lines.text: No, I warrant your grace, you shall not entreat him to a second, that have so mightily persuaded him from a first.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: An you mean to mock me after, you should not have mocked me before: but come your ways.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Now Hercules be thy speed, young man!

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: I would I were invisible, to catch the strong fellow by the leg.
They wrestle

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: O excellent young man!

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: If I had a thunderbolt in mine eye, I can tell who should down.
Shout. CHARLES is thrown

lines.speaker: duke frederick
lines.text: No more, no more.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: Yes, I beseech your grace: I am not yet well breathed.

lines.speaker: duke frederick
lines.text: How dost thou, Charles

lines.speaker: le beau
lines.text: He cannot speak, my lord.

lines.speaker: duke frederick
lines.text: Bear him away. What is thy name, young man

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: Orlando, my liege the youngest son of Sir Rowland de Boys.

lines.speaker: duke frederick
lines.text: I would thou hadst been son to some man else: The world esteemd thy father honourable, But I did find him still mine enemy: Thou shouldst have better pleased me with this deed, Hadst thou descended from another house. But fare thee well thou art a gallant youth: I would thou hadst told me of another father.
Exeunt DUKE FREDERICK, train, and LE BEAU

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Were I my father, coz, would I do this

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: I am more proud to be Sir Rowlands son, His youngest son and would not change that calling, To be adopted heir to Frederick.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: My father loved Sir Rowland as his soul, And all the world was of my fathers mind: Had I before known this young man his son, I should have given him tears unto entreaties, Ere he should thus have ventured.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Gentle cousin, Let us go thank him and encourage him: My fathers rough and envious disposition Sticks me at heart. Sir, you have well deserved: If you do keep your promises in love But justly, as you have exceeded all promise, Your mistress shall be happy.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Gentleman, Wear this for me, one out of suits with fortune, That could give more, but that her hand lacks means. Shall we go, coz
Giving him a chain from her neck

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Ay. Fare you well, fair gentleman.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: Can I not say, I thank you My better parts Are all thrown down, and that which here stands up Is but a quintain, a mere lifeless block.

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: He calls us back: my pride fell with my fortunes Ill ask him what he would. Did you call, sir Sir, you have wrestled well and overthrown More than your enemies.

lines.speaker: celia
lines.text: Will you go, coz

lines.speaker: rosalind
lines.text: Have with you. Fare you well.
Exeunt ROSALIND and CELIA

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: What passion hangs these weights upon my tongue I cannot speak to her, yet she urged conference. O poor Orlando, thou art overthrown! Or Charles or something weaker masters thee.
Reenter LE BEAU

lines.speaker: le beau
lines.text: Good sir, I do in friendship counsel you To leave this place. Albeit you have deserved High commendation, true applause and love, Yet such is now the dukes condition That he misconstrues all that you have done. The duke is humorous what he is indeed, More suits you to conceive than I to speak of.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: I thank you, sir: and, pray you, tell me this: Which of the two was daughter of the duke That here was at the wrestling

lines.speaker: le beau
lines.text: Neither his daughter, if we judge by manners But yet indeed the lesser is his daughter The other is daughter to the banishd duke, And here detaind by her usurping uncle, To keep his daughter company whose loves Are dearer than the natural bond of sisters. But I can tell you that of late this duke Hath taen displeasure gainst his gentle niece, Grounded upon no other argument But that the people praise her for her virtues And pity her for her good fathers sake And, on my life, his malice gainst the lady Will suddenly break forth. Sir, fare you well: Hereafter, in a better world than this, I shall desire more love and knowledge of you.

lines.speaker: orlando
lines.text: I rest much bounden to you: fare you well. Thus must I from the smoke into the smother From tyrant duke unto a tyrant brother: But heavenly Rosalind!
Exit LE BEAU
Exit
